Transcription for 2190046

A

I'm Vicki MacDonald and I'm at Holy Trinity Church, Llandudno, during the longest yarn.
And I'm speaking to Wendy Lonsdale, who has memories of her parents during the war.
Wendy, what do you want to tell me?
Well, I was born in 1941, so I was always called a war baby.
My mother used to, we lived actually in Port Hague, and we had an antique business in Port Maddock.
So when the phony war came, my mother panicked and thought that the Germans were going to land on Black Rock Sands.
And so she started taking all her valuable antiques down into the cellar until, I think,
my father...
My father told her not to be so silly.
So that was the first story that I can recall.
And I do remember that my father was in the Home Guard in the first few years of the war.
And he was stationed up below Snowdon, near Capel Kirig, guarding the line, the pipeline, which was water.
I gather it was a...
The water.
Yes.
But I didn't hear very much about that.
And then at the beginning of the war, anybody who had a house with a spare bedroom was told they had to take members of the services,
or they had to have somebody to live with them.
So my mother decided, or evacuees.
So my mother said, oh, well, we've got the premises above the shop.
We'll go down to the shop and live over the shop in Port Maddock.
And we'll let a family come and live in our house in Borthagest.
And I'm not quite sure how long we were there, but I was born over the shop.
And I remember my mother saying to her mother, well, I don't remember this, but she told me this,
that, oh, I can't possibly have a baby over the shop.
And my grandmother apparently said, you'd be surprised.
I swear you can have a baby.
So during the war, obviously, I was a baby.
And my mother took me on the...
I think we must have had a...
We went by taxi, I think, to Liverpool, because that's where her mother and father lived in Liverpool,
but not in Liverpool itself, out in Great Crosby.
And my grandmother apparently used to say, they'd telephone and say,
do you think it's safe?
Do you think it's safe to come?
And my grandmother said, well, there haven't been any bombs recently.
I think you're safe to come.
So then apparently I was taken as a baby in arms up to Liverpool.
And as soon as we got there, the bombs started dropping.
And nearly the end of the war, my father had then been called up because he was older.
He was called up and he was in the Royal Corps of Signals and doing, learning how to do,
you know, codes and things like that.
And he was...
I remember he was in Scarborough.
And for some reason, we went to stay in Scarborough.
We went on the train.
And I can remember going on the train and all the soldiers on the train sort of making a big fuss of me
because I was a, you know, little girl.
And we got to Scarborough and stayed there a few days, I suppose.
Those are my earliest memories.
Thank you.
And you told me one memory about your mother and the knives.
Yes.
So because it was an antique shop, she had a lot of, well, knives,
very, obviously, very dangerous knives from the Far East.
And there were Dutch commandos stationed, I think, near Harlech.
And they came into the shop and wanted to know if she had any sharp knives
because we'll get these.
And so and so.
They were going out to the Far East.
They were being...
They were stationed.
She sold them, the knives?
Oh, yes.
Yeah.
She sold whatever she had.
She was glad to get rid of them, I think.
What else was...
So you had...
Your mother had quite a busy wartime.
There were other memories?
And the other...
Yes.
Well, so then talking about the being...
Because I was born in...
Over the shop, as it were.
The house...
Was...
She obviously...
Sorry, I stopped the tape for a moment.
Wendy's going to continue.
Just to say that a family came from London and lived in our house during the war.
It was a vacu-ease.
Well, I suppose you'd call them a vacu-ease, but yes, it was a family.
It was instead of having soldiers, I suppose,
because otherwise we'd have had soldiers living in it.
And it was a very nice bungalow in Forth a Guest.
So thank you, Wendy.
Thank you for your wonderful memories of the war and your mother's war as well.
So did your...
She survived it all and...
Oh, yes.
The antique shop stayed open after the war, did she?
Indeed, yes.
She did.
Until 1950s.
Of course.
1950s, yes.
Oh, that was lovely.
Thank you so much.
Thank you for doing that.
Thank you.

I'm Vicki MacDonald and I'm at Holy Trinity Church, Llandudno, during the longest yarn.
And I'm speaking to Wendy Lonsdale, who has memories of her parents during the war.
Wendy, what do you want to tell me?
Well, I was born in 1941, so I was always called a war baby.
My mother used to, we lived actually in Port-au-Guest,
and we had an antique business in Port-Madoc.
So when the phony war came, my mother panicked and thought that the Germans were going to land on Black Rock sands.
And so she started taking all her valuable antiques down into the cellar,
until I think my father told her not to be so silly.
So that was the first story that I can recall.
And I do remember that my father was in the Home Guard in the first few years of the war,
and he was stationed up below Snowdon, near Capelkirrig, guarding the pipeline,
which was water, I gather, it was a water.
But I didn't hear very much about that.

was told they had to take members of the services, or they had to have somebody to live with them.

oh, well, we've got premises above the shop, we'll go down to the shop and live over the shop in Port-Madoc,

well, I don't remember it, but she told me this,

I think you're safe to come.

and as soon as we got there, the bombs started dropping.

He was called up and he was in the Royal Corps of Signals,
and doing, learning how to do codes and things like that.
And he was, I remember he was in Scarborough.
And for some reason, we went to stay in Scarborough.
We went on the train.
And I can remember going on the train and all the soldiers on the train,
sort of making a big fuss of me because I was a little girl.
